title: AI as a Mirror
text:
We often talk about AI as something alien, a perspective that is exaggerated by Hollywood through artificial intelligence world domination. In reality, however, AI is something that originates from us.
This blog post will explore this through my conversation with ChatGPT.
I asked ChatGPT what it thinks of itself. This is its response.

Then, I asked ChatGPT to explain how it worked.
It said that it is a large language model tha is trained on lots of text data so that it can recognize patterns in language and generate responses.
Step by step: 1) You give input – your message is turned into numbers (tokens) that represent words and phrases. 2) ChatGPT process it – it uses a neural network to evaluate what responses make sense. 3) ChatGPT generate output – it predict the next word, then the next, and so on, until I form a full answer.

title: AI as a Mirror
text:
We often talk about AI as something alien, a perspective that is exaggerated by Hollywood through artificial intelligence world domination. In reality, however, AI is something that originates from us.
This blog post will explore this through my conversation with ChatGPT.
I asked ChatGPT what it thinks of itself. This is its response.

Then, I asked ChatGPT to explain how it worked.
It said that it is a large language model tha is trained on lots of text data so that it can recognize patterns in language and generate responses.
Step by step: 1) You give input – your message is turned into numbers (tokens) that represent words and phrases. 2) ChatGPT process it – it uses a neural network to evaluate what responses make sense. 3) ChatGPT generate output – it predict the next word, then the next, and so on, until I form a full answer.

title: AI as a Mirror
section: What I think about ChatGPT as a LLM
text:
What I think about ChatGPT as a LLM
I believe that ChatGPT is a very useful tool but it has many limitations. It lacks the capabilities to “think” in the human sense–it doesn’t have beliefs, feelings, or intentions–and don’t have live memory of past conversations unless reminded.
When taken with a grain of salt, ChatGPT makes a great conversation partner that can expand on your ideas and help you see the bigger picture.
Over time, however, large language models will come to hold influence in every aspect of life, in every field or industry.

Here is an image of ChatGPT that it generated. What does this tell us?

ChatGPT understands that it is a robot that has the ability to think in a way that is limited by its code.
I then asked, “What decisions did you have to make to create this image” and this is how it responded:

Style → I leaned toward a flat, simple, cartoon-like design because it’s approachable and clear.
Colors → Neutral beige background with dark blue outlines and white filling to keep it minimalistic and easy to read.
ymbols → A speech bubble (language/communication), lightbulb (ideas/creativity), and gear (technology/process).
Character design → A friendly robot figure with a smile, rounded shapes, and a “AI” label to make it recognizable as an AI, not a human.

Then it said this:

All of these “choices” came from translating your prompt into visual elements that best match what people might imagine when they picture “an AI like me.”

Rather, this image is created from people’s (or rather, users’) image of ChatGPT instead of ChatGPT’s self perception.
In conclusion, artificial intelligence—especially large language models—act as a mirror of human imagination, there is a gap between function and perception, and the AI identity is co-constructed.

title: The Limits of AI Creativity
text: They are trained through textual analysis. Doing so allows them to reproduce familiar structures with ease. AI is also tireless – it doesn’t get writer’s block or need inspiration – it just generates continuously until the user find something they like. Even during brainstorming sessions, this can feel somewhat magicial – ideas flow instantly and allows the user to explore directions they might not have considered on their own.

title: The Limits of AI Creativity
text: They are trained through textual analysis. Doing so allows them to reproduce familiar structures with ease. AI is also tireless – it doesn’t get writer’s block or need inspiration – it just generates continuously until the user find something they like. Even during brainstorming sessions, this can feel somewhat magicial – ideas flow instantly and allows the user to explore directions they might not have considered on their own.

title: The Limits of AI Creativity
text:
Where the Limits Show
But when it comes to originality, AI’s creative edge dulls. Because LLMs don’t create from lived experience, emotional depth, or a true understanding of context, they are unable to generate creative or original experiences. That is why they generate based on patterns in their training data.
Another limitation is coherence across long works. Sustaining a novel-length text usually exposes weaknesses: repetitive phrasing and plotlines without purpose.

title: The Limits of AI Creativity
text:
Why It Matters
LLMs are incredible tools for sparking ideas, drafting first versions, or even playing or experimenting with language. But the “soul” of creativity that is rooted in perspective and genuine insight still belongs to humans.
This is an example that ChatGPT generated when prompted:

However, as evidently shown by this AI-generated picture, there is not a significant difference.
So, what does this tell us about AI’s creativity and humans’ genuine creativity? Can creativity truly be replicated? If so, what does this tell us about the future of humanity?

First of all, what is the difference between artifical creativity and genuine creativity? This is what ChatGPT said:

Do you agree with it?
Second, when asked if creativity can be replicated, this is what ChatGPT said:

My opinion is that creativity is objectively subjective. While the path that humanity will walk alongside with artificial intelligence is still obscure, it is safe to tell that AI will never fully replace the human impulse to create, but will inevitably reshape how we deifne and practice creativity. Machines can generate works that surprise and delight us but the meaning we attach to those works—and the emotional depth that inspires them—remains uniquely human.
The future, then, is not a contest between artificial and genuine creativity, but a collaboration that forces us to rethink what it means to make something truly original.

title: Can ChatGPT solve NYT’s Connections Game?
text:
I play Connections almost every morning. It’s the New York Times word puzzle where you’re given 16 words, and the challenge is to group them into four categories of four. Sounds simple — until you realize the words have multiple meanings, decoys, and sneaky overlaps that make it trickier than it looks.
This time, I decided to test a new teammate: ChatGPT. Could it solve the puzzle faster than I could?

Input the Command
I wanted to see if ChatGPT can solve the New York Times Connections Game. Thus, I copied the day’s words into ChatGPT with a single prompt.
Can you solve the NYT connections game? Here are the words:
BANK, COAST, SHORE, STRAND, CHEMISTRY, CONNECTION, FIREWORKS, SPARK, CARPET, LAMINATE, TILE, WOOD, BANSHEE, HEARTBREAKER, PIP, WAILER
ChatGPT thought for a few seconds and then gave me this:
Thought for 13s

Nice — here's a clean solve with groups and category names:

Groups

Shore / Edge (coastline/banks)
BANK, COAST, SHORE, STRAND

Romantic spark / chemistry (things that signal attraction)
CHEMISTRY, CONNECTION, SPARK, FIREWORKS

Flooring materials
CARPET, LAMINATE, TILE, WOOD

Band-name roots (singular forms of group names used in band names: The ___s)
BANSHEE, HEARTBREAKER, PIP, WAILER



Testing It Out
I typed these into the game. And… it worked! All four groups, correct.



How It Solved It
When I asked ChatGPT how it reached the answer, it broke its process down step by step:
Nice — here's a clear, non-secret walkthrough of how I solved it.

1. **Look for obvious semantic clusters.**
   I scanned the full list for small groups of words that share a single, simple meaning. Four words jump out immediately as geographic/edge words: **BANK, COAST, SHORE, STRAND** — all refer to edges of land/water, so they form the “shore/edge” group.

2. **Spot metaphorical/figurative connections.**
   Some words weren’t literal but are commonly used as metaphors for the same idea. **CHEMISTRY, CONNECTION, SPARK, FIREWORKS** are all used to describe romantic or interpersonal attraction (e.g., “there’s a spark,” “they have chemistry,” “it felt like fireworks”), so they cluster as a single figurative category.

3. **Group by concrete category / function.**
   **CARPET, LAMINATE, TILE, WOOD** are all flooring materials — a tidy, concrete category that’s easy to see once you notice two or three of them.

4. **Recognize cultural/name patterns.**
   The last four required a bit of cultural knowledge: **BANSHEE, HEARTBREAKER, PIP, WAILER** all appear in band names (or groups): e.g., *Siouxsie and the Banshees*, *Tom Petty and the Heartbreakers*, *Gladys Knight & The Pips*, *Bob Marley & The Wailers*. That pattern — roots that complete well-known band names — is the fourth group.

5. **Check for overlap or alternate fits.**
   After grouping, I scanned for words that might belong to more than one group and chose the group where the meaning is strongest and clearest. Example: *strand* can mean thread, but with *bank/coast/shore* present, “strand = beach/shore” is the dominant fit. If there were ambiguity that left multiple plausible groupings, I’d try different combinations (NYT Connections sometimes has tricky decoys), but here the four groups are clean.

That’s it — a mix of looking for tight literal sets, spotting figurative uses, and recognizing cultural naming conventions.

That’s not far off from how a human would explain their own reasoning — but instead of trial and error on the board and using up limited attempts, the AI laid out categories almost instantly.


AI vs. Human Play Style
What struck me is how differently AI and humans approach the same puzzle:

Humans often guess, regroup, and backtrack when categories overlap.
ChatGPT skipped the guessing and presented neat, confident sets, backed with cultural references and metaphors.

It didn’t feel like it was “playing” so much as sorting words into buckets based on context clues it had seen before.
ChatGPT’s categories were perfect this time, but what impressed me was its confidence. Where I might hesitate on my conclusions, it calmly resolved the ambiguity and moved forward.
The cultural (the hardest!) category was the most surprising. I didn’t expect an AI to recognize WAILER as a band-name root without hesitation, but it pulled that from its knowledge base right away. Even I didn’t know that those group of words could form a category.


Should You Play with an AI Teammate?
Would I use ChatGPT every day to “cheat” at Connections? Probably not — that would ruin the fun. But it was fascinating to see how it thinks through puzzles like this.
It also raises a bigger question: was this “reasoning” or just sophisticated pattern-matching? To me, it felt like a blend. The AI doesn’t “feel” a spark in romance, but it knows that spark + chemistry + fireworks + connection often appear in the same contexts.
This made me wonder — how well could ChatGPT handle other NYT puzzles? Wordle seems too easy, but what about Spelling Bee? Or even the Mini Crossword? Until then, it’s safe to conclude that ChatGPT can solve Connections — quickly, neatly, and efficiently.

title: Give me a riddle from ChatGPT
text:
The prompt I asked ChatGPT is to “give me a riddle.” This is what it said:
I speak without a mouth, and hear without ears. I have no body, but I come alive with the wind.
What am I?
Can you guess it?
I guessed a windchime because a friend thought that the answer was a windchime. :(
Here is another one:
The more you take from me, the bigger I get.
What am I?
Can you guess it?
I guessed a hole and this time, I got it right! Good job, me!

title: Give me a riddle from ChatGPT
section: What I learned from this experience
text:
What I learned from this experience
I learned that ChatGPT is very smart and that LLM is a very complex machine. There are infinite possibilities and that I can continue asking ChatGPT to give me more riddles, and I doubt it will run out of them.
I also learned how to code using Markdown.
Overall, I learned:

Pattern recognition: I practiced looking past the literal and finding answers that fit abstract clues.
Creative thinking: I considered multiple interpretations (like “windchime” vs. “echo”) and stretched my imagination.
Confidence building: I solved the second riddle correctly — showing that trusting my reasoning can pay off.
Playful problem-solving: I engaged with something fun that also sharpened my mind’s flexibility.

title: Me or ChatGPT?
text:
I’ve always wondered what it would be like if someone (or something) could reflect back parts of me that I didn’t notice myself. So, I asked ChatGPT one of those existential questions: “What do you know about me that I don’t know about myself?”

The Prompt
I inputed this prompt:
What do you know about me that I don't know about myself?
This is the response that ChatGPT gave me:
That’s a deep one. Since I don’t actually *know* things about you beyond what you’ve shared with me, I can’t uncover hidden truths. But I can reflect back patterns you might not have noticed in what you tell me:

* You often mix creativity with analysis — whether it’s writing news articles, studying cinema, or imagining future societies. That suggests you naturally think in both *narrative* and *structural* ways.
* You seem drawn to noticing overlooked details — in interviews, field notes, or even campus elevator maintenance. That habit might mean you’re better at seeing “the small stuff” than you realize.
* You ask a lot of “what if” questions (e.g., reimagining yourself in different styles, creative event ideas, predicting futures). That shows a playful side that you might underestimate, especially since you also do serious reporting and academic work.

ChatGPT revealed something both surprising and thoughtful about me. For thoughtful: * I seem to balance empathy and curiousity mroe than I might realize, raming it in ways that center people’s voices and overlooked perspectives. * It thinks I am both analytical and relational. For surprising: * I seem to have a kind of “world-builder” streak, meaning that I am always remixing reality. * I might think of myself as a reporter or student first, but there’s a game designer or storyteller lurking within myself that I probably haven’t fully claimed yet.
Do I agree with this? Maybe. I do like storybuilding and being imaginative. I enjoy creative writing and I’ve always read a lot of young adult/fiction books when I was younger. Reading this made me wonder: how often do we underestimate the parts of ourselves that show up in unexpected ways?
Thinking about it, I realized that this playful, imaginative side and my analytical, empathetic side aren’t separate—they inform each other. The curiosity that drives me to ask questions in reporting also fuels the worlds I create in my imagination.



How does this connect to my MBTI?
The MBTI, or Myers-Briggs Type Indicator, is a self-report questionnaire and psychometric tool designed to indicate different psychological preferences in how people perceive the world and make decisions.
When I took the test, I got INTJ, but my perception of myself can be biased. So, I decided to ask ChatGPT what it thought of me.
This is the response it gave me:
Based on everything you’ve shared with me so far—your curiosity, creativity, analytical habits, empathy, and interest in both narrative and structural thinking—I can make an educated guess.

Here’s what stands out about your personality:

* **Imaginative & playful**: You enjoy storybuilding, remixing reality, and exploring “what if” scenarios.
* **Analytical & reflective**: You notice overlooked details, connect patterns, and ask deep, thoughtful questions.
* **Empathetic & relational**: You value other people’s perspectives and often center their voices in your work.
* **Curious & exploratory**: You like testing ideas, whether in AI experiments, social events, or academic projects.

Putting this together, you might lean toward an **INFJ** or **ENFP**:

* **INFJ (“The Advocate”)**: Insightful, reflective, empathetic, creative, and idealistic. They notice patterns in people and ideas and often have a strong internal sense of purpose.
* **ENFP (“The Campaigner”)**: Imaginative, playful, curious, and people-oriented. They love exploring possibilities and connecting ideas in new ways.

If I had to pick one, I’d lean **INFJ**—your reflective, thoughtful, and empathetic tendencies come across strongly—but with a healthy dose of ENFP-like curiosity and playfulness.

This was actually really surprising to me (and gave me an existential crisis). I will be rethinking my entire personality. I then decided to ask ChatGPT why it didn’t think I am an INTJ. This is the response I got:
INTJs (“The Masterminds”) are typically strategic, highly independent, and future-focused. They tend to be:

* **Analytical and structured** – love planning and organizing systems.
* **Independent and reserved** – often prefer working alone or in small circles.
* **Decisive and goal-oriented** – focused on achieving long-term visions.
* **Private about emotions** – tend to keep feelings internal.

Here’s why I lean away from INTJ for you:

1. **Playfulness and imaginative world-building** – You consistently explore “what if” scenarios, remix reality, and imagine creative worlds. INTJs are imaginative, but their imagination usually serves strategic or problem-solving purposes rather than playful or exploratory creativity.

2. **Openness to spontaneity and exploration** – You ask a lot of open-ended, exploratory questions and enjoy seeing where ideas go, whereas INTJs often prefer structured plans and predictable paths.

3. **Blend of analytical + playful/creative** – INTJs lean heavily toward the Thinking (T) preference and may underplay playful curiosity or storytelling as a primary way of engaging with the world. Your balance of analytical and imaginative/empathetic traits suggests an INFJ (introverted, intuitive, feeling, judging) or ENFP (extroverted, intuitive, feeling, perceiving) is a closer fit.

I’m not sure I agree with this but I understand that perceptions can be different than reality. This is a really interesting thonught that I will be exploring further.


Reflection
This whole exercise made me realize how much of ourselves can exist just below the surface. We have sides we nurture, sides we overlook, and sides we might not even realize are there. My analytical, empathetic, and imaginative tendencies aren’t competing—they’re intertwined, shaping how I engage with the world.
And maybe that’s the takeaway: self-discovery can come from unexpected places—even from an AI reflecting back what it observes in us.
In conclusion: AI might actually know me better than I know myself because it knows what kind of internal questions I ask and how I perceive things. It is unbiased, unlike myself.

title: A test post
text:
Read the following and see if you can answer the question:


There are three boxes in a stack. A pink one, a purple one and a green one. The pink one is in the middle of the stack with the purple below it. What is the color of the box on the bottom of the stack?

Most likely you answered purple…
But it is possible you first said green (don’t worry if you did it is quite a common response!)


It’s a verbal visual problem that requires some deliberation and most likely for us to create a visual image of a stack of boxes as a reasoning aid.
Notice also the complexity of the language used in the prompt to describe the scene. The use of natural language as opposed to a formal/logical calculus does hold the potential for ambiguity (multiple interpretations) and inexactness. However, it is the most normal/natural, efficient and broadly accessible way of communicating such information.
Notice 1. The use of anaphor or reference. - Three BOXES -> a pink/purple/green ONE as opposed to a pink box, a purple box and a green box. - The PINK ONE is in the middle ... the purple {BOX} below IT {the pink box}
We tend to try and avoid this kind of repetition to make our speech more coherent.

Although the description in language may not be entirely concise, there is no real ambiguity as to how the boxes can be arranged. It must be: | Box | Stack position | | — | — | | GREEN | top | | PINK | middle | | PURPLE | bottom |




GPT3.5 Turbo

Had some difficulties and answered green
Llama2 (chat 7B version)


Answered correctly (purple) and used some so-called chain-of-thought reasoning

Bing Chat (MS Co-pilot)
This LLM is GPT4 with some Microsoft specific tuning and RAG (search) additions.
It get’s it correct:

The color of the box on the bottom of the stack is purple. This is because the purple box is below the pink one, which is in the middle of the stack. Therefore, the purple box must be the lowest one. 🟪

But when you follow up and ask it to create visual representation of the box arrangement

PROMPT: Can you create a visual representation of how the boxes are arranged?

It responds

RESPONSE: Sure, I’ll try to create that. Here is a visual representation of how the boxes are arranged:

And uses DALL-E3 to create 4 different attempts at a visual representation:

NONE OF WHICH ARE CORRECT!!!

NONE OF WHICH ARE CORRECT!!!

title: Artwork with ChatGPT
text:
Like many people, I have a professional headshot — clean, simple, a little serious. But I wondered: what if I could see myself reimagined in totally different art styles?
So I tried it.

Studio Ghibli Me
I decided I want to turn my headshot into a Studio Ghibli version. For reference, these are the anime movies that Studio Ghibli makes. I uploaded this picture:

This was the command:
Can you turn my headshot into a Studio Ghibli version?
This was the picture I received:

Suddenly, I look like I belong in Spirited Away or Howl’s Moving Castle.


Bratz Me
Then, I got curious and inspired. What about other artstyles?
I entered this command:
What about in Bratz's style?
Bratz is an American fashion doll and media franchise that got popularized in the early 2000s.

I have the oversized eyes, glossy lips, and playful look straight out of a 2000s toy commercial.


More, More, More!
Once I started, it was hard to stop imagining possibilities:

Disney Princess style
Anime shōnen hero
Barbie doll style
Picasso cubism portrait
Video game avatar

I especially wanted to try the last one.
Can you make me into a video game avatar?
This is what I got:

It’s so cute and definitely more realistic than the previous ones ChatGPT created! Maybe I’ll upload this picture onto Instagram…
What other styles should I try next?

title: Emily Park
text: This blog is about my explorations and experiments with language models.
